title: Election officials want right to delay count in event of severe weather
text:
Election officials are pressing for the right to delay an election count if severe weather puts the safety of their staff at risk on polling day.

The Association of Electoral Administrators (AEA), which represents returning officers who employ count and polling station staff, said existing legislation gave them too little scope for delaying counts during extreme weather.

They fear a snap general election in mid-December increases the risk that severe weather will make travelling far more risky for staff and count observers, and want the powers to postpone a count to the following day in the worst-affected areas.

Bad weather, postal delays and lack of polling staff pose election risks Read more

Councils in exposed or mountainous constituencies are seen as the most vulnerable to heavy snow, severe cold, flooding and gales, but flooding can affect low-lying and urban seats too. During the European Union referendum in June 2016, flash flooding impeded voting in central London.

Last week, the Lib Dem MP Tim Farron warned that his constituency of Westmorland and Lonsdale had been hit by three severe floods at this time of year in the last 15 years.

Council officials in Shetland, part of the Westminster seat of Orkney and Shetland, have warned of the logistical and safety challenges of flying all their ballot boxes to the count centre, which is normally in Kirkwall, the main town in Orkney.

There are 34 inhabited islands in Orkney and Shetland, many of which are connected by ferry and plane and vulnerable to winter gales. A mid-winter election is likely to lead to increased take-up of postal votes in these places.

The last December general election took place in 1923. All recent elections have taken place in April, May or June. The last polling day in winter was on 28 February 1974.

The Met Office said it was close to freezing that day in large parts of Wales, northern England and Scotland. Stornoway in the Western Isles experienced storm-force winds gusting to 69mph (111km/h) and 40mm (1.6in) of rain fell across western England and Wales.

The AEA said election law required returning officers to take “all reasonable steps” to stage a count as soon as practicable after polls closed at 10pm in a UK election, but no later than four hours after polls closed.

Laura Lock, the association’s deputy chief executive, said that put the onus on returning officers to get counting staff and ballot boxes to a count during darkness in mid-winter rather than prioritise safety by postponing the count until the next day.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Rough seas in Orkney, where officials have warned of the dangers of flying ballot boxes to Kirkwall, the main town. Photograph: Alistair and Jan Campbell/UKCI/Alamy

If they fail to start a count within four hours of polls closing, they have to justify their decision to the Electoral Commission in writing. They face losing their election fee, and professional embarrassment, if the commission rules they should not have postponed the count.

Lock said some constituencies covered huge geographical areas. “Do returning officers want to say to their staff, who may need to do a 100-mile round trip to drop off ballot boxes: ‘Do you want to stay home and keep safe and travel in the morning?’” she said.

“Yes, we completely understand we want a quick result [in a general election]. We completely understand the results in one or two seats could reveal who will become prime minister, but at some point the safety of staff has to become a consideration, and we need to keep that at the forefront when we experience a bad winter.”

There are exceptions for European parliament elections. While voting takes place on a Thursday in the UK, the count is delayed until Sunday to ensure counts take place across the EU at the same time. However, the Western Isles has an exemption because working on a Sunday breaches its Sabbatarian tradition of Sunday observance, so its count is delayed until Monday.

An Electoral Commission spokesperson said it was up to the government and parliament to change the rules, but confirmed that returning officers had to take all reasonable steps to count votes “as soon as practicable after the close of poll at 10pm”.

“They will have plans in place to manage the poll in their area, including contingency plans to mitigate any risks to the delivery of their plans, such as inclement weather conditions,” the spokesperson said.
description: Council officials in Shetland warn of risks of flying ballot boxes to count centres
